issue.title: [ENH] Make BaseClassifier abstract with ABC

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

both _fit and _predict should be properly abstract using ABC, rather than just raising an error. 

This cannot be done until all classifiers conform to _fit/fit model. This is linked here

- #1609
- #1608
- #1607
- #1606

this is complicated by the fact that it seems TimeSeriesForestClassifier is used in annotation, benchmarking, forecasting, series_as_features, transformations and utils.

issue.title: [ENH] make _fit and _predict abstract in BaseClassifier

labels.name: refactor
labels.description: Restructuring without changing its external behavior. Neither fixing a bug nor adding a feature.

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
this PR makes _fit and _predict abstract with ABC, and nothing else.

#### Reference Issues/PRs
fixes #1708

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.

 I do not think this is contentious or requires a core developer meeting to approve, for the following reasons

1. The methods are already conceptually abstract, this just allows us to enforce it, implicitly checking all classifiers properly extend the base class. There is no design change. 
2. Using ABC is a completely standard way of making abstract methods in python.
3. ABC is already used in forecasting, benchmarking, clustering and distances. 

any debate about possible other uses of ABC, or changes in the current design utilising ABC, are, in my opinion, secondary to this PR.

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

no

body: Why is this an issue. This is the standard best practice way of doing abstract methods in python why wouldn't we do it. The questions youre asking answers can just be found looking the the documentation for ABC https://docs.python.org/3/library/abc.html.

To answer your questions more directly though I think you're overcomplicating  a lot of it. Literally it will feel the same as the current raise NotImplementedError except it's standardised and more util methods (and ides can better support auto implement functionality):

- which classes would inherit from ABCMeta?
BaseClusterer, BaseClassifier, BaseForecaster etc. Essentially any estimator/transformer that current uses raise NotImplementedError(). This is because ABC just does what that does.

- how do we deal with optional abstract methods?
Optional abstract methods aren't really abstract method. What I think you are wanting is just method overriding. So add a default behaviour and override it in the parent class when you want to change the default behaviour.

- how does this integrate with the tag system in BaseObject? This could be updated using ChainMap.
This wouldn't touch any of this?

- are there any problematic interactions of the public/private nesting pattern fit/_fit?
No.

- we would still like to have capability tags that tell us whether an optional method is implemented or not, e.g., predict_proba or predict_interval. How would this interact with abc?
It doesn't touch it. It's an abstract method it doesn't touch functionality.

- how would downwards compatibility and deprecation work here?
Abc has been supported since 3.6. Again you don't deprecate anything you're just moving away from raise NotImplementedError().

- what about polymorphic estimators, e.g., a pipeline that can act like a transformer or a forecaster? Would abc not complain - - about missing transformer methods if it happens to behave like a forecaster and vice versa?
These aren't abstract methods. But I know they exist and where this happens just raise NotImplementedError. We shouldn't be not using the best practise stuff where it's appropriate just because a niche scenario it doesn't work.

1. which classes would inherit from ABCMeta?
ones with abstract methods currently raising errors if not implemented

2. how do we deal with optional abstract methods?
this has no meaning. The definition of an abstract method is one a subclass *must* implement. Either there is sensible default behaviour, or its abstract. If you want to still raise errors for optional methods, or just pass if it makes sense, thats fine. ABC doesnt stop you doing this. 

3. how does this integrate with the tag system in BaseObject? This could be updated using ChainMap.
not sure why making methods abstract would influence tags at all

4. are there any problematic interactions of the public/private nesting pattern fit/_fit?
how can there be? In fact it enforces correct behaviour at compile time, thats the whole point

5. we would still like to have capability tags that tell us whether an optional method is implemented or not, e.g., predict_proba or predict_interval. How would this interact with abc?
if you want a method optional, it should not be abstract. You just carry on as before. 

6. how would downwards compatibility and deprecation work here?
see chris's answer

7. what about polymorphic estimators, e.g., a pipeline that can act like a transformer or a forecaster? Would abc not complain about missing transformer methods if it happens to behave like a forecaster and vice versa?

dont make them abstract unless they *have* to be implemented by subclasses. I honestly dont understand you points, I think you have misunderstood the meaning of abstract methods, or at least the meaning we teach our first years. If you want to use them in some weird non standard way for forecasting, go for it, maybe there is even a python history of it, I dont know. However, we want to use them in a the purely defined sense as we see it. I dont know why you are persistently blocking such a simple, uncontroversial change for classifiers when ABC is already used in benchmarking (which you managed), and why you did not object to its use in clustering and distances.

@chrisholder 

>> which classes would inherit from ABCMeta?

> BaseClusterer, BaseClassifier, BaseForecaster etc. Essentially any estimator/transformer that current uses raise NotImplementedError(). This is because ABC just does what that does.

I worry a bit about the overhead this causes.
Should not `BaseObject` inherit from it, and nothing else?

> Optional abstract methods aren't really abstract method. What I think you are wanting is just method overriding. So add a default behaviour and override it in the parent class when you want to change the default behaviour.

No, this won't work - there are methods that have no sensible default behaviour and should raise an error. Examples: `predict_interval` for forecasters.

>> how would downwards compatibility and deprecation work here?

> Abc has been supported since 3.6.

Your answer is besides the point: I mean, downwards compatibility with `sktime` itself before we make the change.
Are we certain this won't break custom estimators, for instance? If so, what is the argument to be certain?

>>what about polymorphic estimators, e.g., a pipeline that can act like a transformer or a forecaster? 

>We shouldn't be not using the best practise stuff where it's appropriate just because a niche scenario it doesn't work.

Very shaky argument imo. Polymorphic pipelines are not niche, the pipeline is in fact a central object in `sklearn`-like libraries. I am against abc unless we can ensure that polymorphic pipelines such as the `sklearn` one work properly.

@TonyBagnall 

> I think you have misunderstood the meaning of abstract methods, or at least the meaning we teach our first years. 

I know what abstract methods are and how they work in abc.
A descendant will exception if it doesn't override all the abstracts declared by abc.

>> which classes would inherit from ABCMeta?

>ones with abstract methods currently raising errors if not implemented

Why not `BaseObject`? I don't like that we inherit from multiple classes again.

>> how do we deal with optional abstract methods?

> this has no meaning. [...] Either there is sensible default behaviour, or its abstract. 

Disagreed, I think you don't get the conceptual point here: some base types have methods that have no sensible default *and* descendants do not need to implement them, so cannot be abstract. Example is `predict_quantiles` for forecasters.
overall, I'm happy with answers to 3, 4, 5. I'm not happy and concerned about the others.

Ultimately I don't really mind, if you object we won't do it, but it seems a really odd block to me, clearly missing some nuance in your design. So do you want to strip ABC out of the code base? If so, could you start with benchmarking and then we will follow

>Ultimately I don't really mind, if you object we won't do it, but it seems a really odd block to me, clearly missing some nuance in your design. So do you want to strip ABC out of the code base? If so, could you start with benchmarking and then we will follow

I'm actually in favour since it's elegant. I just don't want to miss an important problem this may cause, such as complicating the extender contract.
I'm really confused now, you blocked my pr making classifier abstract but want it? I'll reopen the PR

> I'm really confused now, you blocked my pr making classifier abstract but want it? I'll reopen the PR

Sorry for not being clear:
* I like the general idea and am quite supportive of it
* I think we need to clarify some open design questions before we can merge the concrete PR

This is not a contradiction! All I want is us avoiding waking up to a bad surprise because we did not think the design through.
I still consider some of my questions above open or not sufficiently answered.

E.g., how does the extender contract concretely change?

issue.title: [MNT] 0.15.0 deprecation actions

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Deprecation actions for the 0.15.0 release:

* changed `check_is_scitype` parameter `msg_legacy_interface` to `False`
* `ExpandingWindowSplitter` had `start_with_window` argument removed. From now on, `initial_window=0` should be used instead of `start_with_window=False`. Contains bugfix https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3953 as the deprecation logic was incomplete.
* Test `test_methods_do_not_change_state` renamed to `test_non_state_changing_method_contract`
* row transformers have been removed, replaced by base class vectorization/broadcasting
* changed default for `default_fc_parameters` in `tsfresh` transformers to follow the default of `tsfresh`, which currently is `comprehensive`
* removed module `transformations.series.compose`. All contents were moved to `transformations.compose`.

Delayed to 0.16.0:
* base class of `ProbabilityThresholdEarlyClassifier` change to `BaseEarlyClassifier`. Unclear what to do here, deprecation action specified breaks the interface compliance tests. Attempt to fix here https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3962 but fails `fit_idempotent` test (unclear why, will drop for this release).
* change of forecaster `cutoff` attribute to `pd.Index` type
